Award.AwardTitle: An integrative approach to quantifying the response of ecological assemblages to anthropogenic stressors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecological stressors such as deforestation, climate change, habitat fragmentation, and invasive species are pervasive throughout the world and can be driven in part by human (anthropogenic) activity. The ability to detect and quantify the impact of these stressors on species communities is critical for maintaining and managing biodiversity and the health of ecosystems. The assessment of anthropogenic impacts on these species communities, however, is a challenging problem given the multivariate nature and multiple facets of biodiversity data. Species differ not only in their taxonomic identities but also in their abundances, evolutionary history, and their role and function in ecosystems. Predicting and understanding how species communities are altered by anthropogenic change and how novel communities function is key to sustaining biodiversity and ecosystem function. This project aims to develop a computational approach for quantifying anthropogenic impacts on ecosystems. The application of these tools to pressing ecological questions will generate much needed information regarding how biological communities are responding to multiple globally important anthropogenic stressors

This project aims to develop new computational methods that integrate multiple sources of biodiversity information to delineate constituent units within species assemblages (defined from here onwards as component communities) and quantify the impact of anthropogenic stressors. The project has two specific aims. The first is to integrate phylogenetic information with species interaction and composition data to identify component communities within ecological assemblages in heterogeneous biodiversity data. The second is to apply these integrative methods to diverse datasets to characterize the changes in composition of ecological assemblages based on responses of these component communities to anthropogenic stressors. For more information on this project visit the PI's lab page at http://denisvalle.weebly.com/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Characterizing biodiversity is the essential first step for measuring its response to change.  Biodiversity is a multidimensional and complex concept that refers to variation in life forms. Species differ in their taxonomic identities, abundances, evolutionary history, and their interaction patterns (e.g., what other species they eat, compete with, or pollinate). Ignoring these differences when assessing the impact of anthropogenic stressors may lead to grossly incorrect conclusions. In this project, we took an interdisciplinary approach to develop methods integrating data from multiple biodiversity facets to better understand how biodiversity is impacted by anthropogenic stressors (e.g., climate change, invasion of exotic species, and forest fires).

Some of the insights generated by these novel methods include: a) determining how anthropogenic factors drive differences in species richness between native and non-native assenblages; b) revealing how an exotic snail invasion influenced habitat use of an endangered raptor; c) uncovering how several breeding bird communities in North America have had a northern range shift, which might be attributable to climate change; d) assessing how urbanization influence leaf and flower phenology at continental scales; and e) exploring how invasions and extinctions have reorganized biodiversity at the global scale. The results of our project show the importance of interdisciplinary approaches to biodiversity analysis. Further, we have shown that some of the methods we developed can be applied to a wider range of problems such as leaf and flower phenology, wildlife movement, and transcriptional regulatory networks.

Broader Impacts: In total, 28 peer-reviewed papers with one in review were produced from this project. Overall, 6 PhD students, 1 undergraduate students, and 6 postdoctoral researched were trained over the course of this project.  We prioritized involving groups traditional underrepresented in STEM including women, Asian, and Middle Eastern students and postdoctoral researchers. Students and postdocs were involved in method development, data analysis, manuscript writing, and presenting oral presentations and posters at international conferences. Further, two postdocs on the project developed an online data science course for graduate and undergraduate students across different disciplines. Another important product that resulted from this award was an open-source R package called ‘Rlda’ that enables the straight-forward implementation of several of these methods developed during this project.
